do you use the weekly's? I have been learning to trade with options and working on learning charting. yes i only trade the weekly's... the key on them is to NEVER hold overnight. the intraday opportunities far outweigh the risk/reward that comes with holding overnight and potentially being in a gap up or gap down that goes against your position and you're automatically down 50% shoot me an email (address is in my profile) and i'd be happy to help you out. chart analysis is my specialty.

Message.Title: GOOG upgraded in AH!!
Message.Msg: It means it will get sold off tomorrow. People will "sell the news." Generally when these analysts are stuck with any stock, they upgrade it for the retail investors to buy and they exit. Now people don't buy the "upgrades" anymore.
Not true. Then why it goes down when downgrade comes.

don't be too naive. Do you really think analysts give up "upgrades" real time? They load up cheap, then upgrade the stock and unload when retail investors get in. Downgrades don't affect stocks much or much longer, unless there is a significant evidence of a negative incident.

Topic.Title: Breaking News: Google just settled lawsuit over stock split. Google will split soon!!!!!

Message.Msg: This is great news too: Should be reflected in the next earnings. An Adobe report that came out last week showed that Google's enhanced campaigns increased CPC by 6% over the past three months. The majority of the increase came from both mobile devices and tablets. The company's enhanced campaigns -- which merge desktop and mobile ads -- are optional for advertisers until July 22. Once the change goes into effect for all advertisers, the CPC rates for mobile bids are expected to increase. This is good news for Google -- and its investors should take note as well.

My take is negative from a trend perspective as I feel that today's gap failure confirms what I felt like coming into the week, GOOG is going to move lower. With that said, the stock is down 4 days in a row and volume was lower today hinting that supply is decreasing at these price for the time being. However, that low supply didn't result in a bump up in the stock which indicates to me that even though supply was lower, demand was just as low. In the last 200 days, GOOG has had 7 4-day losing streaks. Of those 7, 3 saw a 5th consecutive red day (2 of the last 3 in fact) but volatility on that 5th red day was very low and every single one was then followed by a green day (so the 6th day). That suggests there is potential for more bleeding tomorrow but that it shouldn't be a whole lot, and that if it is a red day Thursday should be a green day based on the pattern. I expect GOOG to hold support between $857-$860 tomorrow. When GOOG halts the losing streak at 4 day, the green day is usually pretty solid so that's good news. The bad news though is that with exception to the 4 day losing streak going into the January earnings release, every 4 day losing streak has preceded a move to new lows within 2 weeks. So on a green day I'd expect GOOG to move towards $875 and be looking at the $870 weekly calls. On a red day I don't plan on trading GOOG given its recent history of low volatility on that 5th red day in a row so it's going to be tough to trade the premiums in that scenario. In any event, I'm looking to short this thing the week beginning July 8th, as that's when I believe GOOG will break $847 and move towards $800-$825. "Do you ever buy or sell before 10:30? Do you ever average down? Do you set your sell price right after you buy?" 80% of my trading is done between 9:30-10:30 (i've usually entered a position by 9:42). I don't average down so much as I average in. I have a target/stop loss based on the stock price and sell when one of those
